A porous metal-organic framework (Ni-MOF): An efficient and recyclable catalyst for cascade oxidative amidation of alcohols by amines under ultrasound-irradiations Pouya Ghamari kargar Conceptualization Investigation Software Formal analysis Writing – original draft a ⁎ Ghodsieh Bagherzade Supervision a ⁎ Hamid Beyzaei Writing – review & editing b a Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, University of Birjand, Birjand 97175-615, Iran. Department of Chemistry Faculty of Sciences University of Birjand Birjand 97175-615 Iran aDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, University of Birjand, Birjand 97175-615, Iran. b Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Zabol, Zabol, Iran Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science University of Zabol Zabol Iran bDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Zabol, Zabol, Iran ⁎ Corresponding authors. A novel and green protocol was developed for the synthesis of amides via the reaction of benzyl alcohols with amines in the presence of Ni-MOF named UoB-8 as catalyst. The morphological, structural, and physicochemical characteristics of the Ni-MOF were investigated by FT-IR, XRD, FESEM, EDX, TEM, BET, CHN and ICP analyses. The products were obtained in good to excellent yields, with short reaction times, under ultrasound irradiation (40 ºC) in ethanol as solvent. In addition, low-cost catalyst was recovered and reused at least 5 times without detecting a noticeable reduction in efficiency. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni-MOF Cascade Oxidative amidation Alcohol Ultrasound-irradiation 1 Introduction Amide linkages and their derivatives are important structural motifs that funded in numerous natural products, proteins, peptides, pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals. In addition, they are extensively present in intensifiers of perfume, detergents, color pigments, anti-block reagents, synthetic polymers and lubricants [1–6]. Amidation reactions are usually part of drug formulation [7]. Traditionally, synthetic approach used for amide formation involves the reaction of an amine with a carboxylic acid in the presence of a coupling reagent, which take place usually under harsh reaction conditions, by using highly hazardous reagents, with poor atom-efficiencies and the generation of non-eco-friendly by-products. This entails the expansion of efficient methods for amide bond formation [8,9]. A lineup of novel methodologies such as Staudinger reaction [10], Beckmann rearrangement [11], amino carbonylation of haloarenes [12,13], the Schmidt reaction [14], oxidative amidation of aldehydes [15], transamination of primary amides [16,17], aminolysis of esters [18] have been developed for this purpose. In addition, oxidative amidation of alcohol using several transition-metal based homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts like Au/DNA, Zn, MnO2(IV)–NaCN, and Au-Pd/resin afford alternatives to synthesize amides [19–25]. These catalysts are usually produced in several steps with high costs. Numerous literatures have been reported the synthesis of amides under microwave and ultrasound irradiation [26–31]. Recently, the direct synthesis of amides from readily available and non-toxic alcohols have attracted substantial interest [32–34]. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of coordination polymers with excellent capabilities such as adsorption/separation, sensing and storage [35–40]. They were especially applied as heterogeneous catalysts with high stability and tunable porosity for an extensive variety of organic transformations [41–45]. In continuing our efforts to expand new synthetic strategies for preparing amides [46], we applied Ni-MOF and ultrasound irradiation as promoters of oxidative coupling amines and alcohols under mild reaction conditions There has been no report on the simultaneous use of ultrasound and MOF as energy supplier and the catalyst for direct oxidative amidation. 2 Experimental Instrumental details are given in the Supporting Material. 2.1 Preparation of the Ni-MOF UoB-8 Porous Ni-MOF UoB-8 was prepared similarly to the previously reported procedure for Cu-MOF UoB-5 as follows [46]: A solution containing Ni(OAc)2 (2 mmol) in deionized water (15 ml) was added dropwise to a solution including the synthesized H2bbda as linker (1 mmol, 0.372 g), NaOH 10% (1 ml) and 25 ml of deionized water at room temperature for 15 min under ultrasonic irradiation. The sonication of obtained mixture continued for another 30 min. The resulting precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed thoroughly with EtOH (3×10). The solid was dried in an oven at 100 °C to give Ni3(bbda)2(OAc)2·6H2O. Elemental CHN and ICP analyses suggested a molecular formula of Ni3(bbda)2(OAc)2⋅6H2O (calcd (%): C, 50.62; N 4.84; H, 3.91; Ni, 14.68), which reasonably agrees with the funded amounts (%) of C (50.64), N (4.83), H (3.89) and Ni (14.04). 2.2 General procedure for the direct oxidative amidation A mixture including benzyl alcohol (1 mmol), amine (1 mmol), TBHP (1.5 mmol) and UoB-8 (0.3 mol%) in H2O (5 ml) was sonicated with a frequency of 37 kHz at 40°C for 30 min in air. The reaction progress was monitored by TLC. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, diluted with ethyl acetate (3×10), and the catalyst was separated by an external magnet. The organic layer was dried over MgSO4, filtered and evaporated under reduced pressure. Pure products were achieved by plate chromatography on silica gel as support using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate. All compounds were identified by CHN, and 1H-NMR (in some cases). The spectral data of the obtained amides were compared with those reported in the literature. 3 Result and discussion The synthetic route of UoB-8 and corresponding supported Ni clusters were illustrated in Scheme 1. The synthesis involves three steps: 1) synthesis of H2bbda (4,4ˊ-(1,4-phenylenebis(azaneylylidene))bis(methaneylylidene))dibenzoic acid), 2) ultrasonic dispersion of H2bbda disodium salt as linker, 3) the loading of Ni(OAc)2 under ultrasonic irradiation. The structure of the catalyst was characterized by microscopic and spectroscopic techniques such as FT‐IR, FESEM, XRD, ICP, BET and TEM. In FT‐IR spectra, the broad band observed at region 2400-3350 cm−1 attributed to the stretching vibration of O-H on carboxylic group of H2bbda as well as adsorbed water (Fig. 1 ). The absorption bands at 1683 cm−1 and 1610-1483 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of C=N and C=C, respectively. The band observed around 1281 cm−1 can be significantly assigned to C-O stretching frequency of the ligand H2bbda. The O-H stretching frequency of H2bbda was disappeared in UoB-8 due to complexation with Ni2+ (Fig. 1b). Two strong bands at 1604 and 1390 cm−1 assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the COO groups, respectively. Metal carboxylates are classified according to the values of Δν (Δν = νas(COO) − νs(COO)) [47]. The carboxylate group bonds as a mono-denticulate ligand if Δν of the complex is much large than that of the ligand; a bi-denticulated coordination is present if Δν is significantly much less than that of the ligand; and bridging may occur when the values are close to the ionic values. The calculated Δν values for Ni-MOF nanostructure indicates a bridging coordination mode of the carboxylate groups. Despite many efforts, the crystallites were prepared in small sizes that were not suitable for single crystal X-ray structure analysis. Nevertheless, the phase purity of UoB-8 was confirmed by powder X‐ray analysis (Fig. 2 ) and compared with that of IRMOF‐74‐IV [48]. The sharp peaks in the range of diffraction angles 2θ between 0 and 10° confirm the crystalline structure of the designed Ni-MOF. FESEM and TEM as powerful techniques were employed to determine the size and morphological properties of UoB-8. The FESEM images shown in Fig. 3 a confirmed the nanoscopic scale of the synthesized particles. Also, TEM micrograph (Fig. 3b) corroborated the formation of crystalline nanoscale MOF. The treatment of ultrasound irradiation in this study led to creation a uniform distribution and roughly spherical particles in the range of 35-45 nm. An energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was applied to recognize the elemental composition of UoB-8 nanostructure. As seen in Fig. 3c, EDX pattern clearly approves the elements dispersal of nanoparticles UoB-8. The BET method was used to measure the specific surface area and the pore size distribution using the classical Barrett–Joyner–Halenda model (Fig. 4 ). The N2 adsorption-desorption curves of Ni-MOF displayed the type IV isotherms, which is the typical characteristic of mesoporous materials. The special surface area and average pore diameter were calculated 120 m2/g and 15 nm, respectively. A sharp peak with pore size dispensation centered at ∼15 nm can be observed in BJH desorption (dV/dD) pore volume plot (Fig. 4). TGA analysis was performed to investigate the thermal stability of UoB-8 in the range room temperature up to 700 °C. 3% weight loss was observed from 50 to 150°C, which is related to the evaporation of some water molecules. 37% weight loss in the range 350-600 ºC which is maintained up to 700 ºC may be due to removal of ligand H2bbda. Fig. 5 3.1 Application of Ni-MOF for direct oxidative amidation Catalytic activity of the synthesized Ni-MOF was studied for the preparation of N-substituted benzamides. Parameters including solvent, oxidant, temperature, the amount of catalyst and ultrasound irradiation were optimized in the reaction of benzyl amine (1 mmol) and benzyl alcohol (1 mmol) (Table 1 ). At room temperature, the reaction was studied in the presence of 1.5 equiv of aqueous t‐butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), 0.5 mol% of Ni-MOF and solvents including H2O, EtOH, MeOH, CH3CN (Entries 1-4); the highest yield was achieved in water as solvent. The increase temperature to 40 °C, 60 °C and 80 °C improved the product yields (Entries 5-7). Then, the progress of the reaction was investigated under ultrasound irradiation at different temperatures, in the presence of various amounts of catalyst, and several oxidants (Entries 8-14). Finally, the aqueous reaction of alcohols (1 equiv), amines (1 equiv), TBHP (1.5 equiv) and UoB-8 (0.3 mol%) under ultrasound irradiation at 40 ºC for 30 min was selected as the optimized conditions (Entry 12). The optimized reaction between benzyl amine and benzyl alcohol in the presence of Ni(OAc)2 and H2bbda produced benzaldehyde in 15% yield. To conclude, they can only be effective when coordinated as complex Ni-MOF. Under the optimized conditions, a variety of aromatic/aliphatic amines were reacted with different benzyl alcohols in the presence of UoB-8 (0.3 mol%) under ultrasonic irradiation at 40 ºC to give the corresponding amides in good to high yields (Table 2 ). The tendency of benzyl alcohol and anisyl alcohol (containing electron-donating methoxy group) to react with aniline derivatives decreases in the order p-anisidine > aniline > 4-nitroaniline, which corresponds to their nucleophilicities. The order of reactivity of benzyl alcohols with anilines is anisyl alcohol > benzyl alcohol > 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol, reflecting more stability of benzyl radical intermediates with electron-donating substituents. Generally, the highest yields were obtained with benzyl alcohols and anilines containing electron-donating groups. The reusability and recyclability of the UoB-8 was examined for the oxidative amidation of benzyl alcohol with benzyl amine. UoB-8 was removed by an external centrifuge at the end of the reaction, washed with EtOAc, and dried at room temperature and reused for the next cycle. The recycled UoB-8 was efficient for the amide production even after 5 times recycling (Table 3 ). The FT-IR, FESEM, XRD as well as N2 sorption of five times recycled catalyst confirmed its stability (Fig. 6 ). In addition, the heterogeneity of UoB-8 was evaluated for the reaction of benzyl alcohol with benzyl amine under the optimized conditions via hot filtration and mercury poisoning methods (Table 4 ). In hot filtration experiment, the catalyst was removed after 15 min of reaction time; no significant change was observed in product yield. In mercury poisoning test, Hg(0) is dramatically deactivated the metal catalyst. The reaction didn't proceed after adding about 300 mol eq Hg(0) in 15 min reaction time. These results confirm the heterogeneous performance of the catalyst in the synthesis of amides. A free radical mechanism for direct oxidative amidation in the presence of catalyst UoB-8 was illustrated in Scheme 2 on the basis of the findings of previous researches [22,49,50]. First, the aldehyde is formed from the oxidation of alcohol in the presence of TBHP radicals. Subsequently, the aldehyde (I) reacts with the free amine (II) to afford hemiaminal intermediate (III). The TBHP radical abstracts hydrogen from hemiaminal (III) to give intermediate (IV). Hydrogen abstraction from intermediate (IV) by t-butoxyl radical leads to the production of the corresponding amide. Finally, to prove the efficiency of the catalyst in direct oxidative amidation, product yields and reaction times of the synthesis of N-benzylbenzamide under different conditions were compared with those of our study (Table 5 ). On the calculated TON values, the economic and environmental advantages of our procedure over other methods are clear. 4 Conclusion This paper proposed a green, one-pot, economic, fast and simple procedure for direct oxidative amidation. It also describes the capability of a recyclable and inexpensive nanoporous Ni-MOF (UoB-8) to catalyze the reaction of alcohols and amines to amides. The amides were produced in good to high yields under ultrasonic irradiation in aqueous media. The designed catalyst can be used in other organic transformations. coredata.dc:description: A novel and green protocol was developed for the synthesis of amides via the reaction of benzyl alcohols with amines in the presence of Ni-MOF named UoB-8 as catalyst. The morphological, structural, and physicochemical characteristics of the Ni-MOF were investigated by FT-IR, XRD, FESEM, EDX, TEM, BET, CHN and ICP analyses. The products were obtained in good to excellent yields, with short reaction times, under ultrasound irradiation (40 ºC) in ethanol as solvent. In addition, low-cost catalyst was recovered and reused at least 5 times without detecting a noticeable reduction in efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: A porous metal-organic framework (Ni-MOF): An efficient and recyclable catalyst for cascade oxidative amidation of alcohols by amines under ultrasound-irradiations
